sentences.sentence: The recent tit-for-tat missile strikes by Iran and Pakistan have caught the wider world by surprise.

But for those paying attention to the war in Gaza, triggered by Hamas's barbaric terrorist attack on Israel on Oct. 7, it's not hard to understand why Iran and its proxies are acting the way they do.The tentacles of Islamist regime in Iran stretch far and wide in the Middle East, through a complex network of proxy militia forces that operate and control large swaths of territory.
Hamas, with all its deadly weaponry and tunnel complexes in Gaza, is a permanently bleeding sore lodged inside Israel's body politic that keeps the Mideast in jitters.

And it is funded by Iran.Given Iran's increasing control over Hamas and other terrorist groups in the region, it was expected that, after Hamas launched its dare-devil terror operation inside Israel on Oct. 7, the ensuing violence would expand beyond the borders of Israel and Gaza.Hamas is not the sole impediment to achieving a wider and permanent peace in the Middle East.
Without dislodging Hezbollah - an Iranian proxy with a large fighting force - from Lebanon, the terrorist threat won't be eliminated.

Even if Hamas vanishes from the scene now and Hezbollah and other Iranian proxies in the region are left intact, there is a high likelihood that a few years down the road, Israel and Middle East will be fighting another proxy by another name.The war that was started by Hamas will not stay confined to Israel this time around.
Iran made sure of that by mobilizing its proxies in Iraq, Yemen, Lebanon and Syria.
Iran has a strong foothold in Syria, as it has provided significant support to the Assad regime during that country's protracted civil war.

Syria is of strategic importance to Iran, as it links pro-Iranian militias in Iraq with Hezbollah in Lebanon.In Iraq, the Popular Mobilization Force (PMF) has a network of more than 230,000 fighters that control Iraqi security on Iran's behalf and has recently been targeting U.S. and western assets in Iraq and Syria.

Add Yemen's Houthi guerrillas - which keep Iran's biggest regional rival, Saudi Arabia, on tenterhooks - into the mix and you have a hell of a mess to clear before you can even start dreaming about peace.As Hamas goes underground in the face of the Israeli onslaught, Iranian proxies in the region - Hezbollah, PMF and the Houthis - have begun targeting U.S., Israeli and western interests, including Red Sea shipping.And this is where the Pakistan-Iran missile strikes come into play.

A day before Iran launched a surprise missile attack inside Pakistan's Baluchistan province, it struck U.S. assets in Iraq and Syria, claiming that it was targeting an Israeli spy base in Iraq and terror groups in Syria.Similarly, after it sent missiles and drones into the Panjgur district of Baluchistan the next day, its foreign minister said it was targeting a terrorist organization.
However, local reports from Baluchistan indicate that the missiles hit a few mud dwellings in a barren village, killing two children and injuring three others.

Pakistan retaliated, hitting several dwellings in an Iranian village, calling it a strike against Baluch separatists.Hitting Pakistan to signal Iranian belligerence towards the U.S. and Israel was a bad move.
If Iran's worst fears of western encirclement are true, then it has made another enemy in Pakistan, whose neutrality was vital for Iran's security.
But this chessboard has many moving pieces.Even if Israel is successful in clearing Hamas from Gaza, it will still face a threat from Hezbollah in the north.

The U.S., U.K. and their allies will have to take care of Houthi insurgents, who keep deterring ships by hurling rockets into the Red Sea.Iran has already climbed high enough on the escalation ladder, it would be difficult to climb down now without consequences.

It could open up the Iraqi front to throw the conflict wide open and create more meaningful options of a settlement later, but at the moment its options look limited as domestic dissent and its feeble economy ensures that none of its options will be sustainable.If Pakistan finally brings the hammer down on Iran (though it's not clear at this point that it would), it will have a far-reaching consequence for not both countries.National PostRaheel Raza is a board member of the Council of Muslims Against Antisemitism.

Mohammed Rizwan is a former Pakistani journalist who has worked with numerous international media outlets, including the Washington Post, the Telegraph and the Khaleej Times.Opinion: Defeating Hamas would be a win for the Muslim world(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/opinion-defeating-hamas-would-be-a-win-for-the-muslim-world)Sabrina Maddeaux: Attack on Israel means Canada must toughen measures against Iran(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/attack-on-israel-means-canada-must-toughen-measures-against-iran) !

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
